PCI.BIO: Jessica McManus Warnell is an associate teaching professor in the Department of Management at the University of Notre Dame Mendoza College of Business. She teaches the required undergraduate-level business ethics course, and elective courses in sustainable business, values-based decision-making, and managing millennials. Her research and presentations explore moral reasoning and business ethics curricula, sustainability education, and managing millennials toward effective, ethical leadership. A faculty fellow of the Notre Dame Liu Institute for Asia and Asian Studies, she served as visiting faculty fellow at Reitaku University 麗澤大学, Kashiwa, Chiba, Japan, March – July 2013 with ongoing visits and research. Jessica is a graduate of Saint Mary’s College (BA) and the University of Chicago (MA) and has completed the Notre Dame Executive Education Certificate in Executive Management and Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Sustainability Reporting Certification from LEAD Canada.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: 2013–2014 Gray Family Course Development Grant Recipient
AWARDHONOR.ORG: Notre Dame Center for Social Concerns
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Each year the Center for Social Concerns accepts proposals for $2,500* summer grants to fund the design of a new course or a major redesign of an existing course. These course development grants are a special initiative for faculty interested in incorporating social concerns into their courses through community-based learning. Community-based learning integrates student direct service or other forms of civic engagement, such as research for non-profit organizations, into academic courses.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: Invited Research Fellow and Instructor (4-Month Appointment)
AWARDHONOR.ORG: Business Ethics and Compliance Research Center, Reitaku University, Japan
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Following this fellowship, I have been extended an open offer to return to Reitaku University. Short-term research visit is scheduled for March, 2014. Served as a Research Fellow and Instructor supporting activities in business ethics at the premiere Japanese university in the field; March- July 2013. The consultation will be an opportunity to enhance our presence in this part of Asia, to study teaching of business ethics in other cultural contexts - what we can learn, and what we can share about our work, including Japan's involvement in CSR (ISO 26000, UN Framework for Human Rights, UN Global Compact, and other priority issues in Japan). This Center also holds an extensive network in Japanese and international business that we can leverage to develop our relationships and competencies. Includes teaching, guest lectures and presentations to faculty.

MEMBER.NAME: Academic Advisory Board, McGraw-Hill Contemporary Learning Series
MEMBER.LEADERSHIP: Advisory Board Member, business ethics text development

MEMBER.NAME: International Society of Business, Economics and Ethics
MEMBER.DESC: The International Society of Business, Economics, and Ethics (ISBEE) is the first world-wide professional association to focus exclusively on the study of business, economics, and ethics. Its professional orientation involves people not only with academic competencies but also with practical competencies in responsible management positions (such as vice-presidents and issue managers) and entrepreneurs of medium-size and small companies. Individual membership consists of academicians, managers of business firms and of not-for-profit organizations, and others who have an interest in business ethics. Organizational membership includes companies and other organizations. ISBEE is strongly international in character with members from around the world.

MEMBER.NAME: Corporate Governance and Sustainability International Group
MEMBER.DESC: The Corporate Governance and Sustainability International Group (CGSIG) is an international network initiated by Corporate Governance and Sustainability Research Group (CGSRG) at the Faculty of Business and Law, Leeds Metropolitan University, UK, in May 2009. It aims at promoting international research collaborations and academic exchanges in the areas of corporate governance, corporate social responsibility, business ethics, and sustainable development.

MEMBER.NAME: Globethics.net
MEMBER.DESC: Included as accepted expert on business ethics in worldwide directory. Globethics.net is a global network of persons and institutions interested in various fields of applied ethics. It offers access to a large number of resources on ethics, especially through its leading global digital ethics library and facilitates collaborative web-based research, conferences, online publishing and information sharing. HQ Geneva, Switzerland.

MEMBER.NAME: Society for Business Ethics
MEMBER.DESC: Founded in 1980, the Society for Business Ethics (SBE) is a non-affiliated international association of scholars and others interested in business ethics. Membership in SBE is open to scholars and professionals from all disciplines who specialize in business ethics, and to anyone else seeking the benefits of membership. The Society conducts an annual meeting for the presentation and discussion of new research; issues a newsletter with information of interest to members; and produces the scholarly journal Business Ethics Quarterly .

MEMBER.NAME: Young Professionals Against Poverty (a program of the South Bend Center for Social Concerns)

Association for Practical and Professional Ethics
Net Impact
MEMBER.DESC: Developed from former Students for Responsibility Business network; now international professional, MBA alumni and business scholar and student network devoted to sustainabilty, ethics and CSR in business.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Continued incorporation of timely and relevant material, including adding content related to international business ethics experience following fellowship in Japan. We also continue to use the interactive EthicsGame ethical lens inventory tool.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Managing and Millennials
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Continued to develop this new MCOB course exploring millennials and intergenerational management, incorporating content related to research and book development.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Topics in Sustainable Business
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Updated course to reflect new best practices, changing regulatory and corporate responses to sustainability, and other timely material. Includes 2-3 guest lectures by campus experts.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Business Ethics Field Project
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: All new community-based projects were incorporated for individual students and student teams in response to student interest and community needs. Instruction involves managing external project deliverables to partner organizations, and providing meaningful opportunities for business students to practice their skills in the context of social concerns.
SCHTEACH.OUTREACH: The course operates from the recognition that the business sector offers tremendous potential to impact social issues. Students will apply their skills through projects with local agencies, supervisors, and clients by volunteering with a not-for-profit organization for the duration of the course. An overview of ethical theory will be discussed as we examine the ethical dimensions of social issues. Discussion will allow exploration of the role of business in social challenges. The course allows for macro- (readings, cases and theoretical discussions) and micro- (direct interaction with agency staff and clients) level experience. This semester included incorporation of community consulting requests from colleagues, for example consulting with board of directors at two local organizations with Professor Jerry langley.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Continued development of this course, the first GVV-dedicated undergraduate course of a program that is now part of the curriculum at over 150 colleges and universities around the world. Incorporated material on effective pedagogy gleaned from AOM PDW with international colleagues, and from several writing projects associated with the GVV pedagogy. For the final paper, students are responsible for interviewing two expert sources (faculty or business professionals) in the areas directly relevant to their paper/case study and analysis. This allows students the opportunity to practice professional interactions, apply multidisciplinary concepts and create connections with other courses and professional experiences.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Researched content and coordinated development of new custom textbook for all sections of BAET 20300 taught by Jessica McManus Warnell and Georges Enderle (12 sections/320+ students) (2012-2013) reflecting integrated course content/design for all sophomores in this required course. With Georges Enderle, identified diverse content including assigned readings from Viktor Frankl and modern philosophers, among others, to enhance material from the business ethics textbook. Continued incorporation of timely content and relevant applications for undergraduate business students. The course includes in-class presentations (one per semester) from executives facing ethical dilemmas in their professional lives; opportunity for intimate dialogue with students. Examples include executives from Johnson and Johnson, KPMG, and Deloitte. We also continue to utilize the interactive EthicsGame case simulation and personal ethical lens inventory tools.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Continuous incorporation of timely and relevant ethics cases and other opportunities for application of theoretical foundations of business ethics. Two new ethics simulations incorporated as part of the EthicsGame simulation self-assessment and case analyses. Included a guest session by executives from KPMG, presenting the KPMG Ethical Compass case activity.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Managing & Millennials
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: The course explores opportunities and challenges of engaging millennials, defined as students who have graduated high school since 2000, in the business professions. The course focuses on exploring differences by generational cohort, their impact on organizational culture, and strategies to effectively work within multigenerational cultures, with an emphasis on skill-building for millennials. Topics include social media/privacy/the ethics of technology; issues such as the ethics of loyalty – to self, to firm, to profession – and how these conceptions have changed; and effectively working within multigenerational cultures. Students explore the link between ethical cultures and performance, and methods to leverage the strengths of the millennial cohort toward effective organizations. The course is experiential and discussion-based. In addition to syllabus and course materials preparation, preparation included consultation with ND Career Development and includes self-assessment and vocational discernment tools, including the Harrison Assessment, designed to discern strengths, preferences and opportunities for growth and consider results within context of descriptive data of the millennials - synergies and differences, and opportunities to leverage toward ethical decision making/purpose. Final project involves design of an employee development program for a fictional professional services firm.
SCHTEACH.OUTREACH: Incorporates one guest lecture per semester from young professional - example from Spring 12 is KPMG Audit Senior, a 2008 ND alum.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Topics in Sustainable Business
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Continuous incorporation of new best practices and other case information, as well as discussion of changing regulatory and corporate responses to sustainability concerns. Incorporation of GRI (Global Reporting Initiative) standards in sustainability reporting; final project now includes analysis of GRI and UN Global Compact participation and other standardized metrics for sustainability; collaboration with MBA-level course in sustainability.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Course now includes specific discussion of career discernment and application of GVV principles to the process. Also includes substantive additions to course material derived from my recent publications on GVV pedagogy including assigning the student-life and/or emerging professional individual cases developed by the students.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics

Worked with Jim O’Rourke (Fanning Center) on business writing rubric for evaluation of EG memos to meet ethics course requirements and practice business writing (one goal of EG is communicating principled reasoning to stakeholders).

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics

The ELI and two simulations were be piloted in two sections of BAET 20300 during Spring 2011, with possible adoption across all sections in Fall 2011. Also hosted visit by KPMG executives to participate in "Ethical Compass Toolkit" interactive case with students.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Topics in Sustainable Business
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Incorporation of GRI (Global Reporting Initiative) standards in sustainability reporting; final project now includes analysis of GRI and UN Global Compact participation and other standardized metrics for sustainability; collaboration with MBA-level course in sustainability.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Consistent and regular incorporation of timely material exploring the financial crisis and other current topics in business ethics.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Topics in Sustainable Business
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Incorporation of timely material into rapidly changing course topics. Incorporation of new standards for metrics in sustainability.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: Course focuses on “post decision-making” stage – developing a toolkit of decisions, actions and leadership methods to act on values in the business context. Course is based on global curriculum developed by Mary Gentile (formerly of Harvard University, now independent consultant) in collaboration with the Aspen Institute and Yale University School of Management. Stellar student papers to be included in a published resource of GVV cases as the “Notre Dame Collection”. Curriculum is now taught at schools across the globe including over 100 pilot courses on five continents, and has been featured in the Financial Times, NY Times, BusinessWeek and other trade publications. My course was the first undergraduate, dedicated elective course to incorporate the GVV curriculum. Yale Press and Harvard Business Review will be publishing a GVV book and additional materials in 2010.

SCHTEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
SCHTEACH.PEDINN: c. After a review of several leading texts in summer 09, I incorporated a new textbook for the 09-10 academic year (Audi, Business Ethics and Ethical Business, 2009, Oxford University Press). I developed all new assignments, class presentations, and exams based on the updated materials. In addition to providing a comprehensive introduction to the conceptual foundations of business ethics including theoretical perspectives, discussion of moral reasoning and other key ethical concepts, I created and presented the following topics of my own development to supplement the text material: i. Unit on “Ethical Implications of the Financial Crisis” including up-to-date video clips, readings, in-class discussion and a written assignment that was reinforced by the first MCOB Berges Lecture in Business Ethics, which was required for all of my students ii. Unit on “Sustainable Business” incorporating issues of environmental, social, and financial sustainability and meaningful community impact iii. Discussion of corporate ethics statements including review of several examples and discussion of importance of codifying and integrating strategies iv. Business cases from other sources including current topic of executive compensation v. Explored Catholic Social Teaching and its relevance to business ethics including presentation of scholarly and official Church documents, excerpts from the papal encyclical Caritas in Veritate to which students have been introduced through the Business Law “Business as a Calling” requirement. vi. Incorporated presentation of models of capitalism from an international perspective (i.e. “Nordic” capitalism as recognized in Financial Times) vii. Incorporated multiple external resources to supplement the text including case studies and leadership profiles from various industries to illustrate key concepts

OFF_LOAD_TEACH.TITLE: Introduction to Business Ethics
OFF_LOAD_TEACH.PEDINN: Using summer session as "test" of new components of the requires course - eliminating Ethical Lens Inventory assignment and replacing with second quiz.

OFF_LOAD_TEACH.TITLE: Business Ethics Field Project
OFF_LOAD_TEACH.PEDINN:
Students facilitated all aspects of annual community outreach and funding event for the Boys and Girls Club of Saint Joseph County; classroom work included discussion of the relationship between key ethical concepts and applied community outreach for business. Full course description: Applying business skills to meaningful community-based work allows for the opportunity to develop abilities while examining issues of social justice. The course operates from the recognition that the business sector offers tremendous potential to impact social issues.
Students will apply their skills through projects with local agencies, supervisors, and clients by volunteering with a not-for-profit organization for the duration of the course. An overview of ethical theory will be discussed as we examine the ethical dimensions of social issues. Discussion will allow exploration of the role of business in social challenges. The course allows for macro- (readings, cases and theoretical discussions) and micro- (direct interaction with agency staff and clients) level experience. Written reflection and brief assignments are incorporated.
The class meets once per week for ten weeks. Service hours are completed on the student’s own time according to a schedule established with the instructor and site contact.

DSL.TITLE: Sustainability Minor Capstone: Zero Food Waste/Global Development
Sustainability Minor Capstone: Business Leadership Traits & Sustainability
Directed Readings for Women in Progress Internship, Krobo, Ghana, Africa
DSL.COMMENT: The project will extend Annie's exploration of issues such as the role of business in social issues and the application of business principles to help reduce poverty in developing nations. This will contribute to Annie’s study of business by allowing her to investigate – through both literature and personal experience – the relevance of business in an increasingly interconnected global society and the function of business as a force for good. The readings will focus on the role of business in alleviating poverty and empowering women. These readings will include discussions of the features of successful microenterprise organizations as well as the characteristics of unsuccessful programs. In addition, these readings will cover different strategies used to empower women through microenterprise, including microfinance, assisted implementation, etc.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Test and Quiz bank, Denis Collins' Business Ethics: How to Design & Manage Ethical Organizations (Wiley, 2012)
INTELLCONT.CONTYPEOTHER: Authored quizzes and test bank including 60-75 exam questions (multiple choice, T/F, and essay) and 15-20 quiz questions (multiple choice, T/F) per chapter for this 12-chapter textbook.

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Engaging Millennials for Ethical Leadership: What Works for Young Professionals and Their Managers
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: By 2020, half of America’s workforce will be millennials; by 2050, millennials will represent 75% of the global workforce. Corporate trainings and consultant workshops-for-hire on dealing with this influx abound, but how, specifically and with impact, can young professionals and their companies flourish? In this era of transparency and accountability, explorations of effective organizations are inseparable from considerations of ethical leadership. How can we best prepare the millennials for productive and positive careers? Can managers leverage the unique skills and talents of this generation toward shared goals and business success? Designed for millennials and their managers, we consider how we can cultivate the strengths of this generation toward a new business paradigm. Engaging Millennials for Ethical Leadership provides strategies for optimizing performance at work, drawing on emerging research and complemented with perspectives gleaned from students at a top-tier business school and from a diverse group of corporate executives. The book is structured around millennial capacities and inclinations, with each chapter dedicated to specific characteristics and including manager action items for each. We explore the Giving Voice to Values framework as one promising approach to managing millennials, with its focus on enhancing our capacities for ethical action. Through strategic attention to hiring, training and development, organizations can capitalize on the promise of these new professionals. Companies are compelled to consider these issues for two primary reasons: 1) to attract, develop and retain top talent, these characteristics, dynamics and processes must be explored; 2) we’re in the midst of a new business paradigm, and many of the gifts and proclivities of this generation of emerging leaders can be leveraged to strengthen and grow effective, ethical organizations that will flourish in this context.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: International Society of Business, Economics and Ethics
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Moral Reasoning and Learning Outcomes in Undergraduate Business Education: A Cross-Cultural Exploration

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Game Theory Academy (nonprofit program for financial literacy)
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Trusting the Trust Accounts (case study)

INTELLCONT.TITLE: Six (6) Giving Voice to Values Case Studies and Teaching Notes

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: in Managing Human Resources from the Millennial Generation (William Sauser & Ronald Sims, eds.); Information Age Publishing
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values: Engaging Millennials and Managing Multigenerational Cultures

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: SAGE: Environmental Leadership: A Reference Handbook
INTELLCONT.TITLE: Ethics, Leadership and the Principles for Responsible Management Education (PRME): Sustainability Matters
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT:
This chapter explores current perspectives on environmental leadership and sustainability, implications for leadership, and best practices in the context of the Principles for Responsible Management Education (PRME). The PRME is a useful framework that allows for implementation and strengthening of initiatives toward rigorous, actionable education in sustainable business. As business schools continue to adopt sustainability curricula in recognition of the link among decision making, leadership, and performance measures, the essential task becomes educating emerging leaders to be fluent and capable in the realm of sustainable business. Increasingly, schools respond to the call for emerging professionals with problem solving and implementation skills in addition to conceptual knowledge.
Thus, how can curricula in applied ethics – building on conceptual foundations of business ethics using cases, experiential activities, decision frameworks, peer coaching, and other real-world applications – inform sustainability education? How do principles of authentic leadership prepare students for environmental leadership? We define applied ethics and authentic leadership, consider their convergence within the context of the PRME, and explore this theoretical framework in the global context. The chapter provides explicit examples of international environmental leadership in today’s organizations and concludes with suggestions for further reading.

INTELLCONT.PUBLISHER: Journal of Business Ethics Education: Special Issue: Giving Voice to Values
INTELLCONT.TITLE: “Ask More” of Business Education: Giving Voice to Values for Emerging Leaders
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: Invited contribution to Special Issue on Giving Voice to Values curriculum. Cited by 4

INTELLCONT.TITLE: An Undergraduate Business Ethics Curriculum: Learning and Moral Development Outcomes

PRESENT.NAME: Orientations - MCOB Graduate Business Programs
PRESENT.TITLE: Hitting the Ground Running: Understanding and Leveraging Generational Differences

PRESENT.NAME: Daniels Fund Ethics Consortium Summit
PRESENT.ORG: Daniels Fund, University of New Mexico and New Mexico State University
PRESENT.TITLE: Engaging Millennials for Ethical Leadership: Generations at Work

PRESENT.NAME: Academy of Management 2015 Annual Meeting
PRESENT.ORG: AOM
PRESENT.TITLE: Engaging Millennials for Ethical Leadership
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: By 2020, half of America’s workforce will be millennials; by 2050, millennials will represent 75% of the global workforce. Scholars and business practitioners are questioning whether their tried-and-true approaches to engagement are effective with this generation of students and employees. Corporate trainings and consultant workshops-for-hire on dealing with this influx abound, but how, specifically and with impact, can young professionals and their companies flourish? The topic of millennials in the workplace is often characterized by negativity, lamenting the status of “kids these days….” We argue that these emerging professionals are primed for contribution to ethical organizations based on their upbringing, experiences, talents and proclivities. We will illustrate research highlights indicating these young graduates and early career professionals are open to mentoring and engagement like no other generation. This session is facilitated by a team that models the need for collaborative approaches between the academic and practitioner communities, consisting of a management educator and an educator with an administrative position building bridges with the business community. Incorporating an innovative new web-based, interactive tool for exploring values at work, this PDW will allow participants to collaboratively examine these topics. Participants will gain further insight into what motivates millennials and be able to incorporate specific and actionable strategies for exploring the topic of managing millennial professionals toward ethical organizations into their own teaching and professional activities. Participants will also be exposed to various innovative tools recently created to deliver and incorporate material from the Giving Voice to Values curriculum.

PRESENT.NAME: Association for Practical and Professional Ethics (APPE) 23rd Annual Meeting
PRESENT.ORG: APPE
PRESENT.TITLE: 'Fessing Up: Impact on Consumers and Employees When Companies Admit Wrongdoing
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Businesses, like people, make mistakes. Also like people, they are prone to attempt to minimize the consequences of missteps—if possible, a business will generally avoid accepting responsibility for a mistake to avoid weakening its position in potential future litigation and to deflect consumer and market fallout. Recent trends in regulation, especially SEC Chairman Mary Jo White’s policy to require admissions of wrongdoing as a condition of settlement, increasingly restrict the ability of businesses to avoid taking responsibility. But is this restriction all bad for businesses? Beyond legal implications, corporate admissions of wrongdoing can affect customers and employees. We review research pertinent to this question and suggest that admissions of wrongdoing might have an upside. In particular, we suggest that taking responsibility for mistakes could in some circumstances have a long-term positive impact on the trust of customers as well as the culture and attitudes of employees. We draw on the fields of management, marketing and psychology as well as specific business case examples to examine this possibility. We also identify a number of interesting unanswered questions that might be addressed by future research.

PRESENT.NAME: 20th Annual International Vincentian Business Ethics Conference
PRESENT.ORG: DePaul University
PRESENT.TITLE: Unpacking the Millenial Mystery: Business Ethics and Working with Generational Differences in the Classroom and Corporation

PRESENT.ORG: Business Ethics and Compliance Research Center, Reitaku University
PRESENT.TITLE: The Notre Dame Approach to Business Ethics and Trends in U.S. Business Ethics Education

PRESENT.NAME: Association for Applied and Professional Ethics (APPE) 22nd Annual Meeting
PRESENT.ORG: APPE
PRESENT.TITLE: Assessing Moral Sensitivity
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Moral sensitivity is variously defined as the ability to interpret and identify the moral issues and dilemmas in a situation or the ability to interpret moral aspects of a situation and how they will affect the welfare of another. On one interpretation, moral sensitivity seems akin to moral perception, while on the other, akin to empathy. What is the nature of moral sensitivity? How is it related to moral knowledge? What kind of ability is it? How does it develop? How can it be measured? What empirical tests capture its development and what are the implications of this empirical work for moral education?

PRESENT.NAME: Association for Practical and Professional Ethics (APPE) 22nd Annual Meeting
PRESENT.ORG: APPE
PRESENT.TITLE: Unpacking the Millennial Mystery: Business Ethics and Working with Generational Differences in the Classroom and the Corporation
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Increasing attention in corporate training and development focuses on unique challenges and opportunities associated with engaging Millennial professionals, especially with an eye toward their contribution to effective, ethical organizations. At the same time, business schools continue to develop strategies in applied, relevant and meaningful ethics education. The growing importance of ethics education in business schools is no secret, and the need for meaningful application of theoretical considerations is as high as ever. This presentation highlights ethics education in one undergraduate business program, including a dedicated course on “Managing and Millennials,” and the capacity of ethics education for developing the next generation of effective, values-based business leaders. We discuss promising strategies of engaging Millennials for ethical leadership in the corporate context, complemented with perspectives gleaned from students and from corporate executives.

PRESENT.NAME: Responsibilities and Ethics in the Conduct of Research
PRESENT.ORG: Notre Dame Graduate School and Office of Research
PRESENT.TITLE: "Recognizing and Approaching an Ethical Problem"
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Presentation to 400 first-year doctoral students students from all disciplines; required workshop on responsible conduct of research and ethics for incoming students.

PRESENT.NAME: Congreso ALENE 2012, Universidad del Salvador
PRESENT.ORG: ALENE: Latin American Association for Business, Economics, and Ethics
PRESENT.TITLE: Moral Reasoning and Learning Outcomes in Undergraduate Business Education: A Cross-Cultural Exploration

PRESENT.NAME: Academy of Management Annual Meeting
PRESENT.ORG: AOM
PRESENT.TITLE: AOM PDW: Lessons Learned on the Front Line: Working with the “Giving Voice to Values” Case Method
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: This PDW is based on the innovative Giving Voice to Values (GVV) curriculum and designed as a ‘train the trainer’ workshop for facilitating a GVV case study. The GVV curriculum is an applied approach to the study and practice of ethics that focuses on empowering participants to act on their values when they encounter a values conflict. It has been used in over 150 schools on five continents (including Harvard, INSEAD and MIT) and is well received by students because of its practical and action-oriented approach.

PRESENT.NAME: Fifth ISBEE World Congress
PRESENT.ORG: International Society of Business, Economics and Ethics
PRESENT.TITLE: Moral Reasoning and Learning Outcomes in Undergraduate Business Education: A Cross-Cultural Exploration
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: The paper explores findings of an assessment of moral reasoning and learning outcomes associated with undergraduate business ethics in schools from two diverse contexts, the United States and Brazil, including a required course in conceptual foundations of business ethics and optional elective courses. Findings of the longitudinal study indicate empirical support for applied curricula and a rubric based on the Four Component Model of Morality (Rest and Narvaez, 1999) is presented as one promising and productive framework. The paper explores approaches with potential for developing emerging business leaders with proclivity toward and capacity for ethical leadership, and discusses the role of institutional support for student development in the area of business ethics.

PRESENT.TITLE: Reinforcing Student’s Core Ethical Commitments through Emphasis of Catholic Social Thought

PRESENT.ORG: Dean of the Undergraduate Program for Business Administration & Assurance of Learning Faculty Committee toward AACSB ethics requirements, FGV-EAESP
PRESENT.LOCATION: Fundação Getulio Vargas-School of Business Administration of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil
PRESENT.TITLE: Competencies Related to Ethics
PRESENT.ABSTRACT: Presentation to curriculum committee at FGV-EAESP, Sao Paulo, Brazil, presented by Maria Cecilia Arruda. Presented ND-MCOB's model - a curricular approach to undergraduate ethics focusing on the three objectives of moral sensitivity/awareness, knowledge, and judgment/action/behavior. Goal to develop preference based on moral principles versus social conventions or personal interests when making a moral judgment.

RESPROG.TITLE: Academy of Management PDW Submission, 2015 Annual Meeting: Engaging Millennials for Ethical Leadership
Comparative Book Review: Business Ethics by Linda Trevino and Business Ethics by Denis Collins
RESPROG.JOURNAL_NAME: (Accepted) Journal of Nonprofit Education and Leadership

RESPROG.TITLE: Fessing Up: Impact on Consumers and Employees When Companies Admit Wrongdoing
RESPROG.DESC: Businesses, like people, make mistakes. Also like people, they are prone to attempt to minimize the consequences of missteps—if possible, a business will generally avoid accepting responsibility for a mistake to avoid weakening its position in potential future litigation and to deflect consumer and market fallout. Recent trends in regulation, especially SEC Chairman Mary Jo White’s policy to require admissions of wrongdoing as a condition of settlement, increasingly restrict the ability of businesses to avoid taking responsibility. But is this restriction all bad for businesses? Beyond legal implications, corporate admissions of wrongdoing can affect customers and employees. We review research pertinent to this question and suggest that admissions of wrongdoing might have an upside. In particular, we suggest that taking responsibility for mistakes could in some circumstances have a long-term positive impact on the trust of customers as well as the culture and attitudes of employees. We draw on the fields of management, marketing and psychology as well as specific business case examples to examine this possibility. We also identify a number of interesting unanswered questions that might be addressed by future research.

RESPROG.TITLE: Moral Reasoning and Learning Outcomes in Undergraduate Business Education: A Cross-Cultural Exploration
RESPROG.DESC: Accepted for publication in Ethics and Responsibility: Global Perspectives, special edition book from Springer on ISBEE papers. Due 2015. The paper explores findings of an assessment of moral reasoning and learning outcomes associated with undergraduate business ethics courses in schools from two diverse contexts, the United States and Brazil, including a required course in conceptual foundation of business ethics and an optional elective course in values-based decision-making. Findings of the longitudinal study indicate empirical support for applied business curricula, broadly, and for the purposes of our exploration, specifically, the Giving Voice to Values program of study. The paper provides tangible examples of curricular approaches with potential for developing emerging business leaders with the proclivity toward and capacity for ethical leadership.

RESPROG_COLL.NAME: with Maria Cecilia Coutinho de Arruda

RESPROG.JOURNAL_NAME: ISBEE (International Society of Business, Economics and Ethics) Proceedings, Springer book publishers

RESPROG.TITLE: Perspectives on Business Ethics in the Japanese Tradition: Implications for Global Understanding of the Role of Business in Society
RESPROG.DESC: (Accepted for presentation, APPE Annual Conference Feb. 2015) The paper examines how exploring conceptual approaches to business ethics from the Japanese tradition can enhance our global approach to social and environmental sustainability, including discussion of a framework for understanding the embeddedness of the business in society. We explore several important attempts to provide a universal business ethic, and examine contributions of Japanese thought to these frameworks. Considering the traditional approaches of sanpoyoshi, or tri-directional business (impacting the buyer, seller, and society), and kyosei, which can mean “living and working together for the common good”, the research explores the relationships between the private sector, government, and civil society. Further, we examine the related notion of moralogy, which has been described as a virtue-based stakeholder approach to business. We suggest that these concepts promote adopting the conception of the “homo socio-economicus” model by combining elements of the “homo economicus” and the “homo reciprocans.” Through interviews with Japanese scholars and practitioners and exploration of Japanese cultural traditions, we present an overview of these approaches. With this perspective, we cite the case of the Tohoku earthquake and Fukushima nuclear disaster as one illustrative example. We hope that this understanding of the embeddedness of business in society based on Japanese experience can contribute to a global conception of the role of business in society, relevant for the United States as well.

RESPROG.TITLE: Reinforcing Students' Core Ethical Commitments through emphasis of Catholic Social Thought
RESPROG.DESC: Submitted to the Journal of Catholic Higher Education

FACDEV.TITLE: Notre Dame and BYU: Leading the Way in Ethics Education
FACDEV.ORG: Wheatley Institution and Marriott School of Management, BYU; University of Notre Dame
FACDEV.DESC: The University of Notre Dame and Brigham Young University will meet six times on the gridiron between 2012 and 2020. As scholars at these Christian Faith-Based Institutions, we seek to utilize the spotlight of these events to shine light on the shared gospel-based underpinnings and aspirations we have for the development and practice of virtue-based living in our respective communities. By bringing together university leaders and prominent scholars, we seek to fortify our united front in the battle against societal forces trending against virtuous living. We hope to engage our respective university constituents (students, faculty, staff, alumni, etc.) through speeches by respected leaders and through the provision of substantive scholarly work by our professors. In so doing, we seek to build understanding of and commitment to our common purposes, as well as gaining an understanding of and appreciation for each other’s theology and culture with regards to ethical living.

We have identified and invited a number of persons from both academia and business who are engaged in just that—developing and delivering ethics training in new and interesting ways. We have also invited a number of companies with interests in this topic. Our hope is to foster a conversation through which we will get a good handle on what is currently new, and what might be possible going into the future given needs."

FACDEV.TITLE: Giving Voice to Values Faculty Convening
FACDEV.ORG: Giving Voice to Values, Babson College
FACDEV.DESC: This faculty convening of a select group (approximately 20 faculty members from around the world) focused on teaching, curriculum development and research related to the GVV curriculum. This curriculum, developed by Mary Gentile (Harvard Business School, Aspen Institute and Babson College, in collaboration with Yale University), focuses on developing skills in values-based decision making with an emphasis on specific application in the business context. Our MCOB GVV course, BAET 30300, is the first dedicated GVV undergraduate course in the history of the program. Mary invited me to discuss our experiences with the course. The workshop was an opportunity to meet with other faculty teaching the course to enhance our offering at MCOB. Specific areas on which I've been focusing on include rooting the course firmly within the undergraduate ethics curriculum, developing applications within core business functions, expanding the course’s reach, and continuing to develop its relevance to the MCOB “Ask More” framework of individual integrity, organizational effectiveness and greater good.

FACDEV.TITLE: Connecting Silos: Sharing Ideas & Best Practices in the Teaching of Professional & Research Ethics
FACDEV.ORG: Center for Professional Responsibility in Business and Society & the National Center for Professional and Research Ethics
FACDEV.DESC: Invited participation in this convening of a small group of practitioners from across disciplines to share best approaches and challenges in teaching professional responsibility and ethics.

FACDEV.TITLE: Association for Applied and Professional Ethics (APPE) Annual Meeting
FACDEV.ORG: APPE
FACDEV.DESC: Presented paper, An Undergraduate Business Ethics Curriculum: Learning and Moral Development Outcomes, at this annual meeting of the APPE. The paper, presenting year-one results of the three-year longitudinal study of moral reasoning and other outcomes associated with the Mendoza College of Business undergraduate ethics curriculum, provides information for exploring our curriculum and enhancing the undergraduate experience. The meeting was a helpful opportunity to present to and receive feedback from top scholars in business ethics education. This feedback has been quite useful in further developing the three-year study.

FACDEV.TITLE: Global Reporting Initiative (GRI) Sustainability Reporting Certification
FACDEV.ORG: LEAD Canada
FACDEV.DESC: 16 hour training. "The prevalence of sustainability reporting is growing and has converged around the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI), the world’s most widely used framework. LEAD is the first and most experienced GRI-certified training provider in North America. LEAD’s GRI-certified training initiative has been endorsed by the Certified General Accountants Association of Canada (CGA-Canada), the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Shareholder Association for Research & Education (SHARE). Participants in GRI-certified courses will receive their course completion certificates directly from GRI. LEAD is the first and most experienced GRI-certified training provider in North America and Jantzi-Sustainalytics is the foremost expert in analyzing corporate sustainability reporting and performance."

FACDEV.TITLE: Memorization or understanding: are we teaching the right thing? & Peer Instruction Workshop

FACDEV.DESC: Designed for faculty teaching intro level courses, designed to enhance learning outcomes and facilitate meaningful discussion. Eric Mazur is the Balkanski Professor of Physics and Applied Physics at Harvard University
